description: a(n) = a(n-3) + a(n-5) with initial values 1,0,0,1,0.
comments: From _Bob Selcoe_, May 19 2014: (Start)Since a(n) is a recurrence of the form a(n) = a(n-F1) + a(n-F2) where seed values are a(0)=1 and a(n)=0 for n<0 exclusively (that is, a(n) is the number of compositions of n into parts F1 and F2), apply the following definitions and operations:I. Generally, let m' be the maximum and k' be the minimum values such that n = F1*m' + (F2-F1)*k'.Ia. In this sequence, since F1=3 and F2=5, then n = 3*m' + 2*k'. So for example, when n=49, m'=15 and k'=2 because 49 = 3*15 + 2*2.II. Let G be the greatest common factor of F1 and F2 (in this sequence, G=1).IIa. When n = F1*m' + (F2-F1)*k' is null, a(n)=0. When G=1, the greatest such value of n is F1*F2 - F1 - F2. So in this sequence, the greatest value of n where a(n)=0 is 3*5 - 3 - 5 = 7.III. THEN GENERALLY: a(n) = Sum_[(m'-(F2-F1)*i)!/(k'+F1*i/G)!*(m'-k'-F2*i/G)!]; i=0..j where j is the maximum integer value such that j<=G*(m'-k')/F2.IIIa. In this sequence, a(n) = Sum_[(m'-2*i)!/(k'+3*i)!*(m'-k'-5*i)!]; i=0..j. For example, when n=49, m'=15 and k'=2; therefore j=2 because 1*(15-2)/5 = 2.6. Thus a(49) = 15!/2!*13! + 13!/5!*8! + 11!/8!*3! = 105 + 1287 + 165 = 1557.IV. THEREFORE: a(n) can be solved in closed form for all recurrences of this type.Alternatively, a(n) equals the sum of the diagonal in the binomial triangle (i.e., Pascal's Triangle, A007318) with slope (F2-F1)/F1, starting at C(m',k'). In this sequence, the slope is 2/3. (End)
